subject: Test diagnostics (was Re: [junit] Help plz...)
msgSnippet: I found this thread interesting and helpful, because it forced me to check my premises: I occasionally insert temporary System.out.println statements when
messageBody:
I found this thread interesting and helpful, because it forced me to
check my premises:

I occasionally insert temporary System.out.println statements when
debugging a single test case (usually during a refactoring that caused
the test case to break) and don't see a great problem with this.
Nonetheless, J.B. and Vladimir have convinced me that it would be
better to use additional assertions in such situations. Guess I need to
delve into the javadocs more to discover all the additional assert
methods JUnit makes available... :-)

John

J.B. Rainsberger wrote:

>If a test fails, then you are making an assumption that does not hold
>true, either about the test or the production code you are testing. Add
>more assertions.
>
This sounds like a good habit to get into!

>If I cannot pass a test right away, I throw away my production code and
>try again. If I'm wrong twice in a row, I might throw the test away and
>try to write it again. Typically (according to my experience) that's
>faster than doing all this diagnostic stuff.
>
>
It's sooo easy and seductive to keep diagnosing and diagnosing...

--
